column4: Hello, is there a way to force an eject command against the loopback device?
what do you want to do?
I'm trying to install a game through Wine and it requires that the disks be switched.  Wine is clinging to the files on the iso, and won't allow and umount. I'm trying to force the issue
wine is not standard ubuntu app, nevertheless, why dont you mount all your iso's at once
say one as D: another as E: another as F: drives and so forth
I would, but the game is pretty stubborn about insisting it be in the same drive
Never said it was, I was just looking for a way to force an eject to the loopback
sounds fancy they way you state it
you mean unmounting a mounted iso?
Can't umount, the iso has open file, hence the forcing part. The game is designed to eject an eject command to the disk drive
why dont you just mount another iso on top of the first one?
Or at the very least, it appears that way, it silently fails to work
so the 'ejecting of loopback' you are refering to, are you doing that under wine?
Nope, Wine can't help it's the one holding the files
Looks like I can rename drives on the fly and trick the application into accepting two different locations
The funny part is that I have the disks, but some sort of latency issue if screwing installer.
